gloss: Using someone else's power to intimidate others.
teaser: Ever heard of someone riding on another's coattails? This idiom captures that perfectly.
script: Welcome to Chengyu Bites — your quick summary on Chinese 成语. Ever heard of someone riding on another's coattails? This idiom captures that perfectly. [break 1s] The phrase is: 狐假虎威, hú jiǎ hǔ wēi. [break 1s] 狐 (hú) - fox [break 0.5s] 假 (jiǎ) - to pretend [break 0.5s] 虎 (hǔ) - tiger [break 0.5s] 威 (wēi) - power or might [break 1s] So, the full idiom is 狐假虎威, which literally means 'the fox pretending to use the tiger's power'. Figuratively, it refers to someone who uses the influence or power of others to intimidate or control others. [break 1s] Here’s the story behind it: [break 1.5s] In ancient times, a fox encountered a tiger and was terrified of being eaten. To save itself, the fox cleverly claimed that it was the king of all animals and that if the tiger harmed it, all the animals would retaliate. The tiger, confused but intrigued, allowed the fox to pass, believing it had some power. This story illustrates how the fox used the tiger's fearsome reputation to its advantage. [break 1.5s] Example 1: 他总是狐假虎威，利用他父亲的权力来吓唬别人。 [break 1s] He always uses the power of his father to intimidate others. [break 1s] Example 2: 她在公司里狐假虎威，仗着老板的宠爱。 [break 1s] She uses the boss's favoritism to dominate in the company. [break 1s] Example 3: 这个小团体狐假虎威，常常吓唬新来的成员。 [break 1s] This small group intimidates the new members by leveraging their connections. [break 1s] So, that's 狐假虎威, using someone else's power to intimidate others. Thank you for listening to Chengyu Bites! See you next time for another idiom. [break 1s]
